 Recently and oddly enough, my family had had to deal with this issue on several unrelated occasions. I don't know what the forum rules are for disclosing too many details so I'll not give the full stories. But we have a family member who recently suffered a cardiac arrest. 45 minutes of CPR and was shocked 9 times during that 45 minutes to finally restore a heartbeat. They were subsequently in a coma for three weeks and breathing primarily through a ventilator for two months until they were finally able to be weined off of it.
 
 Twice I was approached about how long I was willing to leave them on life support and I was in the process of getting the family on board with that idea,... when this person started showing signs of improvment.
 
 The topic of this thread is "brought back to life." Take it from someone who's been there and who deals with it (the after affects) every day,... there are no easy answers or explanations. This person doesn't remember anything about the entire ordeal. Like you said, "nothingness." Yet we have them on tape mouthing the words to songs, smiling at jokes, all sorts of facial expressions,... It was cleary more than "nothingness",... it's just not retained by an accessable memory.
 
 Now,.. was this person ever actually "dead?" I don't think so. 
 
 I don't think so, because I will always err on the side of life. The dr.s and nurses were not ready to give up on my family member's behalf and so they pulled them back from the brink of death. 
 
 The only other thing I can add is this; "Death" would have been a lot easier to deal with than a recovery like this. When death occurrs, it's final. It's sad and painful but survivors can heal and eventually move on. Recovery from an injury like this is a life sentence for everyone involved in that person's life. It's for that reason, that I have drafted a "do not recusitate" order for myself. I would never want to put my family through this again.
